journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Structural vibration control using a tunable hybrid shape memory material vibration absorber

article-meta.aff: 1Institute of Mechatronic Engineering, National Taipei University of Technology, Taipei, Taiwan
2Department of Mechanical and Automation Engineering, Da-Yeh University, Changhua, Taiwan
3Graduate Institute of Automation Technology, National Taipei University of Technology, Taipei, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Chun-Ying Lee, Institute of Mechatronic Engineering, National Taipei University of Technology, 1, Sec. 3, Chung-Hsiao E. Rd., Taipei, 10608, Taiwan. Email: leech@ntut.edu.tw

abstract.p: Vibration absorber has been used as an effective tool in the vibration reduction of structure-suffered single-frequency excitation. However, for structures subjected to excitation with varying frequency, an absorber with actively tunable frequency capability may offer more powerful solution. In this study, an absorber that consisted of a spring element made of hybrid shape memory materials was proposed. A cantilevered beam fabricated by superelastic core and shape memory polymer sleeves was employed as the spring element of the absorber. By controlling the electric current through the superelastic core, and thereby the temperature of the shape memory polymer sleeves, the natural frequency of the absorber was tunable. The fabricated hybrid shape memory material absorber was capable of changing its natural frequency by more than 45%. Finally, vibration reduction of a cantilever structure subjected to different harmonic excitations was demonstrated using gain-scheduling control algorithm.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Since Frahm (1911) first invented the dynamic vibration absorber in early 20th century, there have been many studies published in the development of the tuned vibration absorber (TVA) for various applications (Brennan, 2006; Kela and Vahaoja, 2009). Basically, the TVAs only work for a very narrow bandwidth around the designed frequency and should be attached at the location of maximum vibration in the primary structure. However, during service, the TVAs can detune because of the change in forcing frequency or the existing difference between the designed and in situ behavior. Thus, an adaptive tuned vibration absorber (ATVA) that can maintain a tuned condition under these circumstances is more robust in application.

Overall speaking, the most common way of achieving a tunable TVA is to incorporate a variable stiffness element in the absorber. The mechanisms of the variable stiffness can derive from the change in geometry or shape (Brennan, 2006; Ghorbani-Tanha et al., 2011; Kidner and Brennan, 2001; Tiseo et al., 2006), or the adjustment in the material properties. Several materials with controllable material properties have been proposed: viscoelastic solids (Fosdick and Ketema, 1998; Ketema, 1998), shape memory alloys (SMAs) (Rogers et al., 1989; Rustighi et al., 2005; Savi et al., 2011; Tiseo et al., 2010; Williams et al., 2002), ferromagnetic shape memory materials (Faidley et al., 2006; Sarawate and Dapino, 2009), piezoelectric materials (Bonello et al., 2005; Hagood and Von Flotow, 1991), electrorheological fluids (Choi and Park, 1994; Sun and Thomas, 2011), magnetorheological fluids and elastomers (Deng and Gong, 2007; Hirunyapruk et al., 2010; Koo and Ahmadian, 2007), etc. The stiffness of smart materials can be easily varied and controlled; hence, their use in ATVAs is intriguing. The use of ATVAs for this semi-active vibration control, compared with their active control counterparts, usually provides simpler and more stable controller design and is more power efficient in high level of excitation.

Among the smart materials used in the design of TVAs, the mechanical properties of the SMA change with the temperature upon the phase transformation between martensite and austenite. Such a material is inherently simple and compact, and can be employed in a variety of environments including space. However, because of the associated phase transformation temperature hysteresis in heating and cooling, the less dynamic effect of the tuning than static loading, and the unusual extra “softening” between martensite and austenite transformation, a complex control system is required (Rustighi et al., 2005). In order to overcome the above-mentioned shortcomings, the variable stiffness element of the TVA was replaced with a shape memory polymer (SMP) in this study.

SMPs, similar to their SMA counterparts, have the capability of changing their shape upon the application of thermal stimulus (Lendlein and Kelch, 2002). The transition temperature of the shape memory effect is usually closely related to its glass transition temperature Tg. Thus, the SMP is a viscoelastic material with its mechanical properties controlled inherently by temperature. With the temperature raised above Tg, the material undergoes glass transition from glassy state to rubbery state. Accordingly, a significant change in modulus and damping capacity of the SMP is observed (Liang et al., 1997). Therefore, in this study, the spring element of a TVA with cantilever beam configuration has been proposed to be constructed by an SMP sleeve surrounding a NiTi core. The NiTi core serves both as the electric conductor, for carrying the control current in ohmic heating, and as part of the structure. By controlling the current in this hybrid shape memory beam, the stiffness of the absorber can be continuously adjusted without thermal hysteresis suffered by its SMA counterpart proposed in the previous studies, for example, Williams et al. (2002). Finally, an associated control methodology is also discussed and the system is implemented experimentally.

sec.title: Absorber in cantilevered configuration
sec.p: Since in the vibration control using absorber, the effectiveness is predominately determined by the natural frequency of the absorber and the external excitation frequency. The natural frequency of the designed absorber has to be designed first. In this study, an absorber in cantilevered configuration was fabricated as presented schematically in Figure 1. The cantilevered beam that consisted of hybrid shape memory material was utilized as the spring element, while the end mass block at its free end constituted the body part. As the centroid of the end mass block was subjected to concentrated force F and moment M, and the corresponding lateral deflection and rotation were denoted by Y and Θ, respectively, the relationship between the displacements and loadings could be obtained as

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the vibration absorber in cantilevered configuration.

sec.p: By taking the inverse of equation (1), we can write
where the stiffness matrix is expressed as
If the mass of the cantilever beam is assumed to be negligible compared with the end mass block, then the mass matrix of the absorber can be written as

In equation (4), m and IG denote the mass and mass moment of inertia of the end mass block, respectively. With the stiffness matrix and mass matrix obtained in equations (3) and (4), the undamped fundamental frequency of the absorber can be solved from the dynamic equations accordingly
It was found that the fundamental frequency of the absorber ω could be written as

sec.title: Effective stiffness of the hybrid beam
sec.p: In order to fabricate an absorber with tunable natural frequency, the cantilevered beam of the absorber presented in Figure 1 was composed of hybrid shape memory materials. Figure 2 shows the proposed cross-sectional view of this hybrid shape memory beam. The inner NiTi core with diameter dA was wrapped with SMP sleeve on the outside to obtain the total outer diameter of dP. Because the deflection of the assembled hybrid beam was controlled to be within small deformation range, the mechanical bonding on the interfaces due to the pressure fit was assumed to be good and the slippage was negligible. Under the assumption of perfect bonding on the interface and the consideration of bending deflection, the effective bending stiffness of the hybrid cross section, EI, can be written as

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the cross section of the single hybrid beam.
SMP: shape memory polymer.

sec.p: where E and d denote Young’s modulus and diameter of the constituents, and the subscripts A and P represent the NiTi alloy and SMP, respectively.

sec.title: Absorber structure with hybrid shape memory materials
sec.p: A cantilevered configuration with hybrid beam structure was used in the fabrication of the proposed absorber, as shown previously in Figure 1. There were four hybrid beams in parallel forming the spring element of the absorber. Figure 2 presents the schematic diagram of the cross section of the hybrid beam. The NiTi wire with diameter 0.45 mm used in this study was manufactured by Furukawa Electric Co. Since the wire was employed both as the electric conductor for the control current of ohmic heating and as the structural support for the outer SMP sleeves, the chosen NiTi alloy retained its superelastic characteristics during the temperature alteration. The superelastic behavior of the NiTi wire can provide larger elastic deformation range of the absorber structure. If the martensite–austenite transformation occurs within the operation temperature range, then the change in the elastic modulus during the transformation will diminish the tunable effect of the assembled hybrid wire. In addition, the four hybrid beams were connected in series for the control current circuit. Therefore, all four beams were simultaneously heated by the control current or cooled by natural convection.

The SMP sleeve employed in this study was a pyro-condensation cannula sleeve distributed by G-Apex Co. Since only commercially available products were used in this study, the hybrid wire with required outside diameter was fabricated by adding sequentially the sleeves with different diameters. The assembled sleeves were first heated with hot air and then heat-treated uniformly in an oven which generated a required pressure fit between the NiTi core and SMP sleeves.

Before the absorber was fabricated and assembled, specimens for determining the Young’s modulus and damping loss factor of the constituents had been prepared. Both the NiTi alloy and the hybrid beam were bended into U-shaped beams, respectively. The SMP sleeve was assembled sequentially with four tubes of different diameters to reach an outside diameter of 2.8 mm. The U-shaped specimen allowed the applied electric current to pass through the wire in a circuit and the temperature of the specimen to be raised by the ohmic effect. The specimen can be clamped at different lengths to carry out the measurement at different frequencies as mentioned in the following section.

sec.title: Measurement of dynamic characteristics of absorber
sec.p: As mentioned previously, the absorber was constructed in a cantilevered configuration. Therefore, an experimental setup for the dynamic characterization of a cantilevered structure under base excitation was prepared. Figure 3 shows the schematic diagram of this setup. The dynamic signal analyzer (HP 35665A) provided the base excitation signal, which was amplified by the power amplifier (LDS PA100E), to drive the electromechanical shaker (LDS 406). The specimen fixed on the shaker head, thus, was under controlled base excitation. The displacement of this base excitation was measured by an eddy current probe. In the meantime, the induced vibration at the tip of the cantilevered structure was monitored by a laser displacement probe (Keyence LC-2401). By employing the measured vibration response at the tip and the excitation at the base, the frequency response spectrum of the structure could be obtained from the dynamic signal analyzer. Furthermore, by controlling the electric current from the direct current (DC) power supply, the measurement of the dynamic characteristics of the structure at different temperatures was investigated.

caption.p: Schematic diagram for the experimental setup in the measurement of the dynamic characteristics of the cantilevered structure under base excitation.
DC: direct current.

sec.title: Construction of vibration system with attached absorber
sec.p: For the purpose to demonstrate the proposed application of the tunable vibration absorber, a simple cantilever beam with attached end mass block was used as the primary structure. The vibration absorber was then attached to the end mass block as presented schematically in Figure 4. The four hybrid beams of the absorber were arranged in a series circuit. Therefore, the current supplied to the absorber controlled the heating of the hybrid beams simultaneously.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the vibration system with the proposed absorber attached to the end block of the primary cantilever structure.

sec.p: In order to investigate the control effect of the proposed system, a setup with external excitation and control loop was constructed, as shown in Figure 5. By mounting the primary structure on top of the shaker head, the disturbance generated by the shaker simulated the external excitation to the primary structure. In this study, only the disturbance with single frequency was investigated, although the disturbance frequency could be varied. The resulted vibration at the end mass block of the primary structure was monitored by the eddy current displacement probe. This vibration signal was picked up by the AD/DA interface (NI 6008) card and processed with LabVIEW software. The frequency of the measured disturbance was first calculated using fast Fourier transform (FFT) in the LabVIEW. Then, the output command for controlling the current from the DC power amplifier to the tunable absorber was determined by the gain-scheduling algorithm explained later on.

caption.p: Schematic diagram for the vibration control of the primary structure with attached absorber.
DC: direct current.

sec.title: Phase transformation characteristics of shape memory materials
sec.p: The tunable material property of the shape memory materials due to phase transformation was the key mechanism in this proposed system. Thus, the phase transformation characteristics of the used materials were first measured using differential scanning calorimeter (DSC; DSC-Q200, TA Instruments). Figure 6 presents the DSC curve of the NiTi alloy used as the core of the hybrid beam in this study. It is seen that the phase transformation region was between −10°C and 15°C during heating. In other words, at temperature higher than room temperature, the NiTi alloy was at austenitic phase and no phase transformation happened. In other words, this NiTi alloy was in superelastic (SE) state. This was the intended result since the NiTi core served only as an electric conductor for ohmic heating. The major tunable material property change was on the SMP sleeve of the hybrid beam.

caption.p: DSC curve of the NiTi alloy used as the core of the hybrid beam.
DSC: differential scanning calorimeter; SE: superelastic wire.

sec.p: Figure 7 presents the DSC curve of the SMP used as the sleeve of the hybrid beam. There were two coupled peaks in this DSC curve that could relate to the glass transition and melting of this SMP material. The phase transformation occurred at temperature above room temperature. Therefore, at room temperature, the SMP was in its glassy state. When the temperature was raised, the material became more rubber-like and its Young’s modulus decreased. The softening of the SMP at elevated temperature provided the tunable stiffness of the hybrid beam.

caption.p: DSC curve of the SMP used as the sleeve of the hybrid beam.
DSC: differential scanning calorimeter; SMP: shape memory polymer.

sec.p: The dynamic characteristics of the shape memory materials were first investigated at different temperatures. The NiTi wire was clamped at one end as in cantilevered configuration. The inferred Young’s modulus and damping ratio from the first mode’s natural frequency and half-power-point bandwidth are presented in Figure 8. The Young’s modulus increased slightly when the temperature was raised, while the damping ratio remained nearly the same at relatively low magnitude. The dynamic characteristics of the hybrid beam showed different trends with the raise in temperature. The equivalent Young’s modulus decreased rapidly when the specimen was heated. This shows the capability in the material tuning with controlled temperature. In addition, the hybrid beam demonstrated a decreased damping ratio with the raise in temperature. The dynamic characteristics of the SMP sleeve alone were calculated from the previous measurements on NiTi wire and the hybrid beam using composite beam theory (Lee et al., 2008). Both the decrease in Young’s modulus and damping ratio with the raise in temperature were found to be the characteristics of polymer heated above its glass transition temperature (Nashif et al., 1985).

caption.p: Temperature-dependent dynamic characteristics of the shape memory materials calculated from cantilevered beam specimens: (a) Young’s modulus and (b) damping ratio.
SMP: shape memory polymer.

sec.title: Temperature-dependent characteristics of absorber
sec.p: Figure 9 presents the temperature-dependent fundamental frequencies of the absorber constructed with different numbers of SMP layers on the hybrid beam. As the assembly of the hybrid beam with more SMP layers increased the effective stiffness, the natural frequency of the absorber became higher with the number of SMP sleeve assembled. As expected, the natural frequency of the absorber with NiTi core and no SMP sleeve remained approximately unchanged over the temperature range 20°C–90°C. All the other absorbers with hybrid beam showed decreasing frequency with the temperature. It is seen that with more SMP layers assembled on the hybrid beam, the absorber had not only higher natural frequency but also larger tunable frequency range over the same temperature span. For example, the natural frequency of the absorber with four SMP sleeves could be lowered from 23 to 12 Hz when the temperature was raised from room temperature to 90°C. This nearly 50% tunable frequency span would be very promising in application. Nevertheless, the results in Figure 8 showed that with increasing number of SMP sleeves, the measured natural frequency demonstrated more control hysteresis in heating and cooling due to the thermal resistance of the SMP. Under this consideration, the absorber constructed with three layers of SMP sleeve was employed in the following study of the control scheme.

caption.p: Temperature-dependent fundamental frequencies of the absorber constructed with different numbers of SMP layers on the hybrid beam.
SMP: shape memory polymer; SE: superelastic wire.

sec.p: In order to verify the validity of the design equation for the absorber, equation (6), an absorber composed of four parallel cantilevered hybrid beams, as shown in Figure 4, was employed as an example. The parameters associated with this absorber are presented in Table 1. Table 2 shows the calculated and measured fundamental frequencies of the absorber at different temperatures. It can be seen that the predictions were within reasonable accuracy, where the error could be indebted to the neglect of the mass of the hybrid beams and the possible slippage between the SMP layers.

caption.p: Parameters associated with the absorber used in this study.
Predicted and measured natural frequency of the absorber at different temperatures.

sec.title: Temperature-dependent dynamic characteristics of the system with absorber attached
sec.p: For the practical control purpose, the tuning of the absorber was activated by the applied electric current. Therefore, the dynamic characteristics of the system with different controlled currents were measured. Figure 10 presents the frequency spectra of the system at different control currents. Since the constructed system was basically composed of two block masses with two cantilevers in series, there were mainly two resonance peaks at the lower frequency range. With the applied electric current, the system reached the steady state after a short period of transient response by the ohmic heating. It is clearly seen that upon increasing current to the absorber, the resonance peaks shifted to the lower frequency. Furthermore, the sharpness of the resonance peaks increased which denoted the decrease in damping capacity upon heating. The result was consistent with the trend of temperature effect presented in Figure 8.

caption.p: Frequency spectra of the system at different electric currents for controlled heating.

sec.p: Considering that the system was subjected to an external excitation of single but varying frequency, the frequency response of the system could be tuned by the excitation frequency. According to the measured spectra in Figure 10, if the control gain of the current was scheduled as that presented in Figure 11, a theoretical frequency response with lowest system vibration response could be obtained.

caption.p: Gain schedule of the control current over the frequency span and the associated theoretical frequency spectrum under single-frequency excitation.

sec.p: It should be mentioned that the above gain-scheduling control algorithm was based on the discrete control current level adopted in the measurement. At excitation frequency close to the ends of each subregion of Figure 11, there was an abrupt jump in the control current. This could raise a stability concern of the system. Thus, a modification of the scheduled gain using fuzzy control concept was adopted. A trapezoidal participation function was employed instead of step function, and the resulted control gain schedule of the current is presented in Figure 12.

caption.p: Modified control gain schedule with trapezoidal participation function adopted from fuzzy control concept.

sec.title: Performances of the controlled system
sec.p: The frequency responses of the system with different control algorithms are shown in Figure 13. The spectra were measured using swept-sine technique over the interested frequency span. The measured results clearly show the effectiveness of the semi-active absorber system compared with the uncontrolled one. The vibration amplitude of the system was greatly reduced especially over the resonance peak of the original system. Furthermore, the fuzzy control algorithm slightly reduced the vibration at the ends of the subregion in the gain schedule diagram.

caption.p: Frequency responses of the system with different control algorithms.

sec.p: In order to capture the system characteristics in the time domain, the system response due to the control current was presented herein. Figure 14 shows the system vibration response when the excitation frequency was 14 Hz. Since the purpose of this measurement was to understand the time reaction of the system, the response over longer time period was recorded. The controller was turned on at about 5 s, and the control current was applied accordingly. It is seen that the displacement amplitude increased first and decreased subsequently to a steady level as the control current was applied. The main reason for the vibration response of Figure 14 to first increase and then decrease is that the temperature of the ATVA can only be continuously changed. The control current can be discretely adjusted such that the heating rate is altered. During the heating process, however, the material properties change continuously with the temperature. The associated variation in vibration response changed with the temperature (or heating current), as shown in the frequency spectra of Figure 10. In a fixed excitation of 14 Hz, the spectra in Figure 10 show that the response first increases with lower current and then decreases with higher current. The result is consistent with the vibration response observed in Figure 14. The result also demonstrates the robustness of this semi-active control scheme. From this result, it was easy to suspect the effect of the other control algorithms that were based on the instantaneous rate of change with control signal.

caption.p: System vibration response when the excitation frequency was 14 Hz.

sec.p: It is noted that the result of Figure 14 did not demonstrate a fast response in time. Although the heating rate can be easily accelerated by raising the control current, the cooling of the SMA/SMP actuators, like the other heat-activated transducers, usually is a challenge. Because the main goal of this study is on the design methodology and control scheme of this tunable vibration absorber using hybrid shape memory materials, only natural convection was employed in this study. The other techniques to enhance the cooling, such as by forced convection or using thermoelectric chip, can be topics for further study.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A semi-active vibration absorber constructed from hybrid shape memory materials was proposed in this study. The designed natural frequency of the absorber could be continuously tuned over the designed frequency range via ohmic heating by control current. An absorber with tunable frequency from 23 to 12 Hz over the temperature range 25°C–90°C was demonstrated. With the absorber attached to a cantilever structure, a gain-scheduling control algorithm was first used to show its effectiveness in the vibration control with single-frequency excitation. A fuzzy control concept incorporating trapezoidal participation function was employed to further improve the control performance. The time response of the structure system at different excitation frequencies proved the validity of the proposed design. However, the further improvement of the system response by considering the excitation with non-single frequency and speeding the control effect can be topics for future study.

ack.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge the assistance from Dr. F.J. Chen, National Taiwan University, Taiwan, in performing the DSC measurement of shape memory materials.
